journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Theoretical and experimental performance analysis of a synchronal rotary multiphase pump with the inlet gas volume fractions of 0–0.9

article-meta.aff: School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Xu Yang, School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, 28 Xianning West Road, Xi’an, 710049, China. Email: yangxu0924@hotmail.com

abstract.p: A synchronal rotary multiphase pump is a novel positive-displacement pump which is structurally simple and has a higher mechanical efficiency. A mathematic model was developed to predict the working performance of the synchronal rotary multiphase pump when the inlet gas volume fraction of the gas–liquid working fluids varies in the range of 0–0.9. The pump working process was theoretically analyzed based on the calculated results of pressure, temperature and fluid mass in the working chamber. The experiment was conducted to test the steady state performance of the synchronal rotary multiphase pump prototype at different pressure differences and inlet gas volume fractions by using air–oil mixture as the working fluids. The measured results of temperature difference between the pump inlet and outlet, volume flow rate and shaft power consumption were shown to be in good agreement with the calculations. The calculated and experimental results showed that both the volume flow rate and the pump efficiency decreased with the increase of the pressure difference. When the inlet gas volume fraction increased from 0 up to 0.9, the volume flow rate and the pump efficiency were decreasing rapidly. It meant that the inlet gas volume fraction had a significant influence on the pump performance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the petrochemical industry, multiphase pumping is one of the most promising technologies developed for oil and gas production. For the benefit of reducing the production costs, the demand on multiphase pump units is steadily increased, especially in the exploitation of the petroleum resources in remote areas. Being different from the conventional pumps, the multiphase pumps are required to be able to handle the gas–liquid fluids at different inlet gas volume fractions (GVF). Amongst the several types of multiphase pumps, the positive-displacement multiphase pumps present a promising method to handle the gas–liquid fluids with a large difference in the inlet GVF. So far, twin-screw pump is considered to be the typical positive-displacement pump whose reliability has been proven in several real multiphase boosting applications.1–7 The theoretical and experimental investigations of Cao et al.8 and Räbiger et al.9 showed that the twin-screw multiphase pump presented a reliable performance within a fairly wide range of inlet GVF, even at 100% gas for a short period. However, because of the rotors of the twin-screw pump are geometrically complex, its machining precision is required to be very high which results in a higher manufacture cost. This type of pump is also sensitive to the sand particles in the working fluids which maybe destroy the rotor profiles and cause operating failures.

In order to simplify the manufacture and improve the operating flexibility, a novel positive-displacement multiphase pump named synchronal rotary multiphase pump (SRMP) was introduced by Yang et al.10 This type of pump is one of the practical applications of the synchronal rotary mechanism brought forward by Qu.11 The major components of the SRMP are all geometrically simple and easy to manufacture. Theoretical studies on the dynamic characteristic and frictional loss of the SRMP reported by Yang et al.12 showed that due to the rotary cylinder, the frictional losses between the major components were largely reduced and the mechanical efficiency of the SRMP was higher than that of the conventional rotary mechanisms. In order to verify the functionality of the synchronal rotary mechanism as a multiphase pump, Yang et al.12 carried out a preliminary experiment in which the crude oil was used as working fluid. There is still a demand on the investigations of the pumping behavior in handling gas–liquid fluids.

Being similar to the twin-screw multiphase pump, the SRMP presents different pumping behaviors at the different inlet GVFs. Both the flow characteristic and thermodynamic condition in the working chamber vary with the inlet GVF. Generally, when the inlet GVF increases to a higher value more than 0.9, the temperature variations of the working fluids and the flow structures of the leakage flow are much different to that under the lower GVF conditions. In this way, the inlet GVFs less than 0.9 are classified as the lower GVFs and that more than 0.9 are classified as the higher GVFs. A difference should be made between the theoretical model of the lower inlet GVFs and that of the higher inlet GVFs.

The aim of this work was to investigate the pumping behaviors of the SRMP under the condition of lower inlet GVFs within 0 to 0.9. In this inlet GVF range, the thermodynamic model of the working process was treated to be in the adiabatic condition due to the negligible heat exchange between the working fluids and the chamber walls. Furthermore, the flow structure of the leakage flow was modeled as the homogenous flow because the lower gas flow rate even at the higher pressure difference. Based on these assumptions, theoretical and experimental analyses on the working process and performance of the SRMP were made. Primarily the mathematic models of the SRMP were formulated, which could calculate the thermodynamic variables and performance parameters. The followed performance experiment accomplished on a SRMP prototype verified the developed models and provided some practical data for the further improvement of the type of multiphase pump.

sec.title: Design of the SRMP and volumetric model
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 1, the working chambers of the SRMP are formed by three major components: a rotor, a rotary cylinder and a sliding vane. The rotor and the cylinder are supported individually on the different bearing pairs and the outside wall of the rotor remains tangent with the inside wall of the cylinder. Two ends of the sliding vane are assembled respectively with the rotor and the cylinder. The crescent-shaped chamber formed by the walls of the rotor and cylinder is divided into a suction chamber and a discharge chamber by the sliding vane. The suction chamber is connected to a suction port on the cylinder. The discharge chamber is connected to a discharge port on the rotor. Figure 1.
Schematic of the SRMP.

During operation, the rotor is driven by the shaft and then carries the sliding vane to move. The sliding vane in turn rotates the cylinder around its own axis. Due the motions of the three major components, the chamber volume varies gradually and results in the suction and discharge of the working fluids. Considering one working chamber, a working circle (suction-discharge) is completed in two shaft revolutions (0 < φ < 4π) as shown in Figure 1. During a working cycle, the volume of the working chamber can be expressed as a function of shaft angle, φ, as follows (1)

sec.title: Modeling of two-phase fluids
sec.p: Under the present condition, the working fluids are modeled as the two-phase mixtures whose gas phase and liquid phase have the same pressure and temperature. According to the theory of gas–liquid flow, the inlet GVF of the two-phase mixture is defined as (2)α=qv,G,inqv,G,in+qv,L,in During the pump working process, the GVF is a variable parameter due to the variation of the gas-phase density. Neglecting the phase changes of the gas and liquid, the gas mass fraction of the mixture remains constant during the working process and can be calculated by the inflow parameters as follows (3)x=ρG,inqv,G,inρG,inqv,G,in+ρL,inqv,L,in

At any instant, the working fluids in the working chamber are assumed as the homogeneous mixtures. The homogeneous density of the two-phase mixtures is given by the formula proposed by Chisholm13 as follows (4)ρH=1x/ρG+(1-x)ρL The specific heat capacity of the two-phase mixtures is defined as (5)cp,H=xcp,G+(1-x)cL

sec.title: Models of flows through the suction and discharge ports
sec.p: During operation, the working fluids are sucked into the working chamber through the suction port during the suction process. When the working chamber is connected to the discharge port, the high pressure fluids outside flow back into the chamber through the discharge port until the beginning of the discharge process. During the discharge process, the working fluids are discharged out through the discharge port. The static pressure drops of the inflow through the suction port and the backflow as well as the outflow through the discharge port are mainly attributed to the sectional changes of the flow paths. As the average mass velocities through the suction and discharge ports are considerably fast, the two-phase flow therein can be modeled as homogeneous flow whose gas phase and liquid phase have the same velocity.

According to the modeling discussions about two-phase flow through the flow path with sectional changes in Chisholm,13 when the ratio of the downstream to upstream pressures is no less than 0.9, the maximum error introduced by assuming no gas density change over the device will be less than 10%. In such case, because of the pressure decreases during the suction and discharge processes are considered to be small, the compressibility of the two-phase mixtures can be neglected in the present models. Then the mass flow rates of the inflow and outflow can be expressed as follows13 (6)qm,s=As(2ΔpsρTP,s/ks)1/2 (7)qm,d=Ad(2ΔpdρTP,d/kd)1/2 The pressure drop coefficients of the suction port and discharge port, ks and kd, can be calculated by the formulas proposed by Chisholm13 as follows (8)ks=(Cσ)-2-2(Cσ)-1+1 (9)kd=(Cσ)-2-2σ-2(C-1-1)-2σ-1+1 where the contraction ratio, σ, is the ratio of the downstream and upstream areas, and the contraction coefficient is a function of the contraction ratio which is given in Chisholm13 as follows (10)C=10.639(1-σ)1/2+1

The flow direction of the backflow is opposite to that of the outflow through the discharge port, so the mass flow rate of the backflow also can be calculated by equation (9). It should be note that downstream and upstream areas which are used for the calculation of contraction ratio for the backflow are different with that of the outflow.

sec.title: Models of leakage flows
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 2, in the SRMP, internal leakages most likely occur at such places, the radial gap between the rotor and cylinder, G1, the axial gaps between the vane ends and the cylinder end-faces, G2, the gaps between the vane sides and the vane slot, G3, and the axial gaps between the rotor and cylinder end-faces, G4. According to the dynamic characteristic of the SRMP, the sliding vane sides keeps being contact with the vane slot during operation, so the leakage through the gap G3 is negligible. Besides, according to end-face motion analysis of Yang et al.,14 the relative velocity between the rotor and the cylinder is small and contact seals are used at this leakage gap to reduce the leakage loss. Therefore, the leakage at the gap G4 is also negligible in the leakage modeling. Figure 2.
Leakage gaps in the SRMP.

In the radial gap G1, because of the radial clearance is much smaller than the axial length of the rotor, the leakage flow can be treated as one-dimensional flow through a narrow channel with a variational section. As shown in Figure 3(a), the leakage path model is developed along the outer surface of the rotor. The channel height is expressed as (11)γ(θ)=[Rcy 2-(e-γ0)2sin2θ]1/2-(e-γ0)cosθ-Rro Figure 3.
Models of leakage paths: (a) radial gap between the rotor and cylinder, (b) axial gap between the vane end and the cylinder end-face.

In the axial gap G2, the leakage flow is also treated as one-dimensional flow as shown in Figure 3(b). During operation, the channel height remains constant in the flow direction, but the channel width varies with the shaft angle and can be expressed as (12)w(ϕ)=(Rcy 2-e2sin2ϕ)1/2-ecosϕ-Rro

Referring to the leakage analysis of a synchronal rotary refrigeration compressor reported by Yang et al.,15 the influence of the wall velocity of the leakage gap on the leakage flow is much smaller than that of the pressure difference, so the walls of leakage gap are assumed to be stationary in this model. Besides, under the present GVF condition, because of the gas mass fraction is no more than 0.015, the temperature variation of the two-phase leakage flow in the leakage gap is anticipated to be small even at a higher pressure difference. In this way, the heat exchanges between the leakage flow and the gap walls can be neglected and the two-phase leakage flow is modeled as the adiabatic flow in the present investigation.

From above analysis, leakage flow through each of the leakage gap can be model as one-dimensional two-phase flow through a narrow channel in the adiabatic condition. The experimental results reported by Fourar et al.16 and Ali et al.17 shown that the flow structure of the two-phase flow through the narrow channel was determined by the volume flow rate of each phase. For a given liquid flow rate, at the low gas volume flow rates bubbles flows and fingering bubbles flows were observed. When the gas volume flow rate was increased, the flow became chaotic with no apparent structures. At the much higher gas volume flow rates, annular flows were observed.

As shown in Figure 3, the inlet and outlet conditions of the leakage flow are respectively defined by the fluid status in the discharge and suction chambers. Due to the compressibility of the gas-phase, the GVF in the discharge chamber is lower than that in the suction chamber and the local GVF of the leakage flow is increased along with the leakage path. Generally, at a certain pump inlet GVF, the leakage volume flow rate of each phase is dominated by the pressure difference between the two chambers. Under the condition of a lower pressure difference, the leakage volume flow rates of the gas phase and liquid phase is very low. Bubbles flow or fingering bubbles flow is the most likely flow structure appears in the leakage flow at this situation. When the pressure difference increases to a higher value, the leakage volume flow rate is increased and the GVF of the mixture in the discharge chamber is decreased to a lower value. Due to the increase of the local GVF in the leakage gap, the gas volume flow rate is increased along with the leakage path and the flow structure varies with the flow displacement in the flow direction. In such case, it is hard to use one kind of flow structure to describe the leakage flow in the gap. However, under the present condition of pump inlet GVFs (0–0.9), the gas volume flow rate at the inlet of the leakage gap is also anticipated to be low and bubbles flow is the most likely flow structure appears in the initial part of the leakage path.

In order to simplify the leakage flow model, the two-phase leakage flow is modeled as the homogenous flow whose gas phase and liquid phase has the same velocity. Using the homogenous model of two-phase flow, the conservation equations of mass, momentum and energy for the compressible and viscid leakage flow can be expressed as follows (13)1ρHdρHdz+1ududz+1γdγdz=0 (14)dpdz+ρHududz+fρHu24γ=0 (15)cp,HdTdz+ududz=0 in which the two-phase friction factor, f, is evaluated as for a single-phase flow through the leakage gap with rough surfaces. The formulas for the laminar and turbulent flow mechanisms are respectively expressed as follows9 (16)f={96Re-1Re<4000[2log(2γk)+0.97]-2Re≥4000 where the Reynolds number, Re, is defined by the homogeneous fluid properties. The homogeneous density of the two-phase mixture is given by equation (4) and the homogeneous viscosity is defined by the relation proposed by McAdams et al.18 as follows (17)μH=1x/μG+(1-x)/μL

Combining with the state equation of the gas, the flow parameters such as the velocity, pressure and density of the two-phase flow along the leakage path can be obtained by solving the above conservation equations. The boundary condition is given by the pressure and density in the discharge chamber and the pressure in the suction chamber. Then the leakage mass flow rate for each of the leakage gap can be calculated by (18)qm,le=ρHuwγ

sec.title: Models of the thermodynamic process and power consumption
sec.p: According to the first law of thermodynamics for an open system, the energy conservation equation for the working volume can be derived. Neglecting the kinetic energy and the gravitational potential energy of the working fluids, the differential energy conservation equation at any shaft angle is expressed as follows (19)δQdϕ=dUdϕ+Σhoutδmoutdϕ-Σhinδmindϕ+pdVdϕ in which both the thermodynamic and physical parameters are defined by the two-phase fluids which modeled as homogeneous mixture in section ‘Modeling of two-phase fluids.’ In the present investigation, the gas-phase is regarded as an ideal gas. Besides, under the present working condition, the gas mass fraction is very small and as a result, the compression heat of gas-phase can be easily absorbed by the liquid-phase with a slight temperature increase of the two-phase fluids. In such case, the heat exchange between the working fluids and the chamber walls is anticipated to be small, so the thermodynamic model is assumed to be in an adiabatic condition. Then the differential equation of the pressure and temperature variations can be expressed as (20) (21)dTdϕ=pdVdϕ+∑[δmindϕcp,H(T-Tin)]m(xRg-cp,H) Combining with the gas state equation, the volumetric model and the mass flow models, the differential equations can be solved by using the fourth-order Runge–Kutta method which gives the transient pressure and temperature in the working chamber. Then other transient parameters such as density and local GVF of the mixture also can be obtained.

On the basis of the simulation results of the thermodynamic process, the indicated work in a working cycle can be calculated by integrating the differential work over the shaft angle range of 0 − 4π. Then the average indicated power consumption of the pump can be expressed as (22)Pi=-n60∫V(0) V(4π)pdV According to the theory of homogeneous two-phase model, the gas phase and liquid phase have the same velocity. Then the effective power consumption exerted to the working fluids in the net flow rate can be defined as follows (23)Pe=(1-x)qmρL(pd-ps)+xqm∫ps pd1ρGdp
The shaft power consumption of the SRMP is expressed as follows (24)Psh=Pi+Pf where the frictional loss, Pf, can be calculated referring to the frictional loss analysis of Yang et al.12

sec.title: Experiment setup
sec.p:
The experimental work was performed to test the steady-state performance of the SRMP prototype in handling gas–liquid fluids within the inlet GVF range of 0–0.9. In the experiment, the two-phase working fluids were mixed by the air and the N32 machine oil. The main dimensions of the SRMP prototype and operation specifications are given in Table 1. Table 1.
Operating specifications and main dimensions of the SRMP prototype.
Parameter Value
Volumetric displacement (cm3/rev) 158
Rated shaft speed (r/min) 400
Temperature at inlet (°C) 40
Suction pressure (MPa) 0.3
Discharge pressure (MPa) 0.3–2.1
Oil density (kg/m3) 863
Kinetic viscosity of oil at 40 °C (mm2/s) 31.7
Specific heat capacity of oil (J/kg K) 1904
Inlet gas volume fraction 0–0.9
Rotor radius (mm) 57
Cylinder radius (mm) 63
Rotor length (mm) 70
Sliding vane thickness (mm) 8
Assembly radical clearance (µm) 46
Assembly clearance at sliding vane end (µm) 21

As shown in Figure 4, the experimental bench consisted mainly of a SRMP prototype, a static mixer, a buffer tank, a main choke valve, a gas-phase loop and a liquid-phase loop. The SRMP prototype was driven by an electric motor. A torque-speed transducer which linked with a measuring instrument was coupled between the pump and the motor for the measurement of the shaft speed and the shaft power. In the gas-phase loop, the gas was taken from the air tank which was connected to an air compressor. The oil was pumped by an oil injection pump from the oil tank. The gas phase was mixed with the liquid phase in the static mixer just in front of the pump inlet. The two-phase fluids were sucked into the SRMP and discharged out to the buffer tank which was connected to the pump outlet. After the depressurization by the main choke valve, the oil of the two-phase mixture was injected into the oil tank for recycle and the air was released back to the atmosphere. In this experimental bench, the global operation parameters of the SRMP performance such as the volume flow rates of both phases, the temperatures at the inlet and outlet, the average shaft power can be measured. Figure 4.
Experimental bench.

sec.title: Analysis of the thermodynamic process
sec.p:
In order to analyze the steady-state working performance of the SRMP, the transient thermodynamic parameters in the working chamber during a work cycle were simulated by using the models established in the section ‘Mathematic models.’ Figure 5 shows the simulation results of the pressure variations in the working chamber during a working cycle (φ = 0 − 4π) at an inlet GVF of 0.5, 0.7 and 0.9 respectively, with a suction pressure of 0.3 MPa and a discharge pressure of 1.1 MPa. It is observed that the pressure increases rapidly after the shaft angle of 2π where the working chamber begins to be open to the discharge port. The reason is that the high pressure fluids flow back to the pump chamber through the discharge port and results in the gas-phase compression in a short period. The variations of fluids mass in the chamber are shown in Figure 6. Although the volume of the working chamber is decreasing after the shaft angle of 2π, the fluid mass in the working chamber keeps increasing until the beginning of the discharge process. Figure 5.
Pressure variations in the working chamber at the different inlet GVFs and a pressure difference of 0.7 MPa. Figure 6.
Mass variations in the working chamber at the different inlet GVFs and a pressure difference of 0.7 MPa.

It is also can be seen from Figure 5 that the difference between the pressure curves at different inlet GVFs is very small. This indicates that the indicated power consumptions at different inlet GVFs are almost equivalent. Because of the compressibility of the mixture is increased when the inlet GVF increases, the relative amount of back flow mass presents a higher value at a higher inlet GVF as shown in Figure 6. This indicates that the proportion of the useless power consumption for discharging the back flow increases with the inlet GVFs and results in a decrease of pump efficiency.

Figure 7 shows the calculated and experimental results of temperature differences between the pump inlet and outlet at different inlet GVFs and pressure differences. It is observed from the simulated curves that the temperature differences are almost negligible at a lower inlet GVF. But at a higher inlet GVF, such as α = 0.9, the temperature difference becomes obvious and increases with the pressure difference. The reason is that for the case of lower inlet GVF, because of the liquid mass fraction in the working chamber is much bigger than the gas mass fraction, the gas phase is fully cooled by the liquid phase during the compression process. But when the inlet GVF increases to a higher value, the cooling capacity of the liquid phase is no longer to handle the higher compression heat and results in an obvious temperature increase. Figure 7.
Experimental and calculated temperature differences between the pump inlet and outlet at different inlet GVFs.

It is also observed from Figure 7 that the experimental values of the temperature differences are lower than the theoretical values, especially at a higher inlet GVF and a higher pressure difference. This could be explained as follows. In the theoretical model, the two-phase flow in the work chamber is assumed to be adiabatic and the heat exchange between the work fluids and the cylinder walls is neglected. However, during operation, the cylinder is immersed in the housing case of the pump which is full of lower temperature fluids, a part of the compression heat in the work chamber can be absorbed by the external cooling. This results in the differences between the experimental values and the calculated values by using the adiabatic models. From above analysis, when the inlet GVF increases, the temperature of the two-phase mixture in the discharge chamber is increased. In such case, when the inlet GVF increases to a higher value, the heat exchange between the working fluids and the cylinder walls becomes more significant due to the increased temperature difference. Referring to the comparisons between the experimental and calculated results shown in Figure 7, the predicting error of the present temperature model is increased when the inlet GVF increases. In this way, it can be concluded that the adiabatic thermodynamic model is no longer suitable for the pump performance predicting at a higher inlet GVF more than 0.9 and the heat exchange between the working fluids and the cylinder walls should be considered in the theoretical model.

sec.title: Analysis of steady-state working performance
sec.p:
The calculated and experimental volume flow rates at different inlet GVFs and pressure differences are shown in Figure 8. It is observed that the calculations agree well with the experimental results, although some discrepancies exist. At a certain inlet GVF, the volume flow rate decreases with the pressure differences due to the increased leakage loss. At a lower inlet GVF, such as α = 0.5, this decrease is not obvious within the pressure difference range of 0–2 MPa. But, when the inlet GVF increases to a higher value, such as α = 0.9, the volume flow rate decreases rapidly with the increase of the pressure difference. This can be explained by the increased leakage loss caused by the inlet GVF changes as shown in Figure 9. In the general, it can be concluded that the inlet GVF exercises a significant influence on the pump volumetric efficiency. Figure 8.
Experimental and calculated volume flow rates at different inlet GVFs. Figure 9.
Nondimensional leakages at different pressure differences.

Figure 10 shows the comparison of calculated and experimental results of the average shaft power consumption at different inlet GVFs and pressure differences. It is observed that at each of the inlet GVF, the agreement between measured and calculated values is fairly good within the test ranges of pressure differences. Figure 10.
Experimental and calculated average power consumptions at different inlet GVFs: (a) α = 0.5, (b) α = 0.7, (c) α = 0.8, (d) α = 0.9.

At a certain inlet GVF, the shaft power consumption increases with pressure differences due to the increased power demand. From the analysis in ‘Models of the thermodynamic process and power consumption’, the shaft power consumption consists of the indicated power consumption and the power loss caused by the friction. As shown in Figure 10(a) to (d), the broken lines represent the indicated power consumptions and the friction losses are given by the indicated powers subtracted from the total powers. It is observed that at a lower pressure difference, the frictional loss occupies a considerable proportion of the power consumption and results in the lower pump efficiency as shown in Figure 11. During an increase of the pressure difference from 0.1 MPa up to 1.8 MPa, the pump efficiency presents an increase at the first stage and then decreases afterwards due to the decreased effective power consumption. Figure 11.
Experimental and calculated pump efficiencies at different inlet GVFs.

Referring to the analysis in the section ‘Analysis of the thermodynamic process’, the influence of the inlet GVF on the indicated power is very small. Besides, referring to the frictional loss analysis in the SRMP reported by Yang et al.,12 the fractional loss is dominated by the shaft speed and the pressure difference. Therefore, the shaft power curves for different inlet GVFs are almost equivalent to each other as shown in Figure 10(a) to (d). Because of the power demand for boosting the gas phase is less than that of the liquid phase with the same volume flow rate under present condition, the effective power consumption is decreased when the inlet GVF increases. Moreover, the decreased net volume flow rate also causes the decrease of the effective power consumption. In such case, when the inlet GVF increase from 0.5 up to 0.9, the difference between the effective power and the total power is increasing distinctly, especially at the higher pressure differences as shown in Figure 10(a) to (d). This indicates that at a higher inlet GVF, the pump exhibits a lower efficiency due to the large amount of useless power consumption for discharging the backflow in the discharge process.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A mathematic model was developed to predict the working performance of a SRMP in handling the gas–liquid fluids within the inlet GVF range of 0–0.9. The steady state performances at different inlet GVFs and pressure differences were tested in the experiment by using air–oil mixtures as working fluids. The measured results of the performance parameters such as the temperature difference between the inlet and outlet, the volume flow rate and the shaft power consumption presented good agreements with the calculated results.

In the SRMP, the two-phase mixture is compressed by the backflow through the discharge port and results in a large amount of power loss. At a certain inlet GVF, both the volume flow rate and the pump efficiency are decreased when the pressure difference increases. The inlet GVF has a significant influence on the pump performance. As the inlet GVF increasing from 0.5 up to 0.9, both the volume flow rate and the pump efficiency decrease rapidly. The SRMP exhibits a lower efficiency at a higher inlet GVF.

In the theoretical model, the two-phase fluids in the SRMP were assumed as homogeneous mixtures and the heat exchange between the mixture and the cylinder was neglected. However, for the analysis of the pump performance at the higher inlet GVFs more than 0.9, a new theoretical model would be required in the further investigation. It is also necessary to test the transient operating parameters of the work chamber which are much useful in a more detail analysis of the pump working process. These investigations will be reported later.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) [grant number 50476053].
